instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: So I have on the bench an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> tonight and It has me stumped. With board only out on the table, when I plug in a MS I get no PP3V42 but has a light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 2.6V. On <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> I'm getting 18v on pins 4 & 7, but no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>. I replaced <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and at first it seemed to work, had MS light, PP3V42 was present as well as PPBUS. After a few min I tried to turn it back on and nothing. Just a fading green light. It seemed like I fixed it but not back to not working. I tried to trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ON</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>OFF_L</SIGNAL> but nothing happened.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message:
Post the actual voltage for <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Also check for <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 2V
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: 0V

Also, The magsafe light fades after about 35 seconds.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message:
18V steady at F6905?
If yes, post <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages.
If not, change <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: I have 18V on both pins of F6905.  Will create another post of voltages for <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: Diode mode to ground at L6995?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message:
Change again <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and be sure to get good solders.
Check all traces in the area.
If needed, change <CAPACITOR>C6991</CAPACITOR>/96 too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: changed <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> twice, same result. will change caps next. tricky area being next to ram slot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: Ok, changed <CAPACITOR>C6991</CAPACITOR>/C996 and still same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: So weird. I got PP3V42 and PPBUS to show up for a min, then it went away again. Also, the magsafe light fades away until I turn off then turn back on the power supply. Even when they showed up temporarily, no fan spin. I'm wondering if maybe something is pulling it down. Or if the SMC is bad.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: Input voltage at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> is stable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: yes. I wonder if I need to order some new <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> ICs vs pulling them from donor.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: Be sure to have good traces and solders first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: Confirmed all pins around <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> are connected to the vias around it and touched up solder joints. What other components around it could influence it not to put out <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message:
This chip doesn't have an external feedback network.
Replace <RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR>, just in case.
Try another L6995 too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: ok

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: Replaced those and no change

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: This board sucks. But I want to figure out what is wrong so I can document it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: Post again <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> voltages and diode mode to ground at L6995.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: So I found something out, When I put my red multimeter probe on Pin 9 of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and hook up charger, I get a pulse of <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> rail. SO that tells me the chip is trying to put 3.42V out but something is stopping it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: Did you change L6995 too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power, weird issue
threads.message: I did. It is fixed. There was a broken via right above <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR> (<SIGNAL>3V3S5_VFB_R7270</SIGNAL>). Ran a wire from <RESISTOR>R7270</RESISTOR> into a via to L7220 and now have a working machine. Holy smokes this was a tough board. But it is back in the chassis and running Sierra like a champ.
